title: Comparative Assessment of Sap Flow Modeling Techniques in European Beech Trees

graphical_abstract.introduction: The study compares sap flow modeling techniques in European Beech trees using linear models, random forests, extreme gradient boosting, and neural networks over a five-year dataset.
graphical_abstract.key_findings: Linear models provide comparable prediction accuracy to complex models (RF, XGBM, NN) and can efficiently estimate long-term integrated sap flow with less computational effort.

dataset.location: Central Slovakia, in a 65-year-old European Beech forest

methodology.analysis: Six variants of datasets with different input ranges and conditions were used to model sap flow.

results.LM: Had the maximum prediction power when shifted by 1 hour of global radiation.
results.NN: Exhibited relatively poor prediction power compared to other machine learning models.
results.RF and XGBM: Performed comparably well to LM except in drier conditions.

graphical_abstract.conclusion: Simpler linear models can be as effective as more complex machine learning models for modeling cumulative sap flow over longer periods, providing a practical and computationally efficient alternative.
